subject: Public Speaking
title: All-or-Nothing Thinking About Speeches
description: A quick win: understand All-or-Nothing Thinking About Speeches.

hook.text: You stumble over one sentence and conclude: That was a disaster. I ruined the whole thing.

buildup.text: All-or-nothing thinking splits outcomes into perfect or terrible, with no room for good enough in between.

discovery.text: Cognitive research shows most speeches land in the middleâ€”decent, useful, forgettableâ€”and that's perfectly fine.

twist.text: Audiences judge speeches as a whole, not as a collection of individual moments. One stumble rarely ruins the impression.

climax.text: Letting go of perfection isn't lowering standards â€” it's accepting that communication is messy and human.

punchline.text: A good speech doesn't need to be perfect. It needs to connect.
